metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Here are 5-10 key legal issues extracted from the document:
• The infringement of trademarks and passing off of goods by defendants as those of the plaintiffs.
• The status of the plaintiffs' trademark "VOLVO" as a well-known mark within the meaning of Section 2(1)(zg) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
• Registration of the plaintiffs' trademark "VOLVO" in various classes, including Classes 1, 2, 16, and 37, under the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
• The licensing agreement between plaintiff no.1 and plaintiff no.2 regarding the use of the trademark "VOLVO".
• The right to restrain defendant companies from using similar marks that may infringe on the plaintiffs' trademarks.
• The validity and effect of a global deed of assignment executed by plaintiff no. 1 in favor of plaintiff no. 2, which assigned the trademark "VOLVO" to the latter.
• The relevance of Aktiebolaget Volvo of Sweden v. Volvo Steels Ltd. of Gujarat (India), (1998) 18 PTC 47, a judgment recognizing the status of the plaintiffs' marks as well-known trademarks.
• The issue of domain name registration of "www.volvobuses.com", "www.volvobuses.in", and www.volvotrucks.in by the plaintiffs and its relevance to the case.
metadata.decision_summary:
Here is a comprehensive summary of the case:

**Case Details**

* Case No: 2023/DHC/000868
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
* Reserve Date: February 1, 2023
* Decision Date: February 7, 2023
* Parties:
	+ Plaintiff: Aktiebolaget Volvo (AB Volvo) and its group companies, including Volvo Trademark Holding AB and Volvo Car Corporation
	+ Defendants: Volvo White Paints Industries, a partnership firm comprising defendants no.2 and no.3

**Background**

The plaintiffs are the registered proprietors of the trademark "VOLVO" in various classes of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, including India. They have been using the mark since 1915 and have acquired reputation and goodwill in the market. The defendant companies allegedly started infringing on these trademarks by using a similar name ("Volvo White Paints Industries") for their business activities and website.

**Legal Issues**

The plaintiff alleged that the defendants are committing trademark infringement, passing off, and dilution of their well-known mark "VOLVO". They claimed relief under Sections 28, 29, 34, 35, and 56 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, as well as for permanent injunction, damages, and costs.

**Arguments**

Plaintiff's Arguments:

* The plaintiffs have established usage and reputation in the "VOLVO" mark since 1915.
* The defendants' use of a similar name and trademarks is likely to cause confusion among consumers.
* The defendants are attempting to pass off their products as those of the plaintiffs.

Defendants' Response (none filed)

**Court Findings**

After examining the pleadings, evidence, and arguments presented by both parties, the court observed:

1. The plaintiffs have successfully established that they are the registered proprietors of the trademark "VOLVO" in various classes.
2. The defendants' use of a similar name ("Volvo White Paints Industries") is likely to cause confusion among consumers and dilute the reputation of the plaintiffs' mark.
3. The defendants' infringement on the plaintiffs' trademarks constitutes an actionable offense under the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

**Decision**

The court granted the following relief in favour of the plaintiffs:

1. Injunction
The court issued a permanent injunction restraining the defendants from using the trademark "VOLVO" or any marks deceptively similar to it, as well as from passing off their products as those of the plaintiffs.
2. Damages
The court awarded costs of ₹50 lakhs (approximately $62,000 USD) in favour of the plaintiffs.

**Order**

"I.A. 1921/2023 (O-XIII A R-2, 3 & 6 of CPC for Summary Judgment) and CS(COMM) 198/2022: 

This Court on Monday, February 7, 2023:

Perused the records and notes of arguments.

Observations with Reasoning:

The plaintiffs' suit for interim injunction is allowed. Costs in favour of the plaintiffs."

Signed,
Justice Amit Bansal

Delivered through Hand.

--- PAGE 1 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 1 of 11 
 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
% 
 
 
 
     Reserved on :   1st February, 2023  
            
 
 
 
    Decided on   :   7th  February, 2023 
+  
CS(COMM) 198/2022 & I.A. 4963/2022(O-XXXIX R-1 & 2 of CPC) 
 
 
AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.  
 
  ..... Plaintiffs 
Through: 
Mr. Pravin Anand with Ms. Vaishali 
Mittal 
and 
Mr. 
Karan 
Kamra, 
Advocates. 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
VOLVO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.   ..... Defendants 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
None. 
 
CORAM: 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
 
JUDGMENT 
 
I.A. 1921/2023 (O-XIII A R-2, 3 & 6 of CPC for Summary Judgment) & 
CS(COMM) 198/2022  
 
1. 
The present suit has been filed seeking relief of permanent injunction 
restraining the defendants from infringing the trademarks of the plaintiffs, 
passing off their goods as that of the plaintiffs‟ and other ancillary reliefs. 
PLEADINGS IN THE PLAINT 
2. 
The case set up by the plaintiffs in the plaint is as follows: 
2.1. Plaintiff no.1, AB Volvo, plaintiff no.2, Volvo Trademark Holding 
AB and plaintiff no.3, Volvo Car Corporation (hereinafter collectively 
referred to as „the plaintiffs‟), incorporated under the laws of Sweden, have 
their core business in transportation and automotive sector, including the 
business of manufacturing spare parts, accessories and ancillary parts for 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 2 of 11 
 
vehicles under the trademark „VOLVO‟. 
2.2. Plaintiff no.1, incorporated on 5th May, 1915, executed a global deed 
of assignment in favour of plaintiff no.2, who became the subsequent 
proprietor of the plaintiffs‟ trademark „VOLVO‟ and subsequently licensed 
the use of the trademark „VOLVO‟ to plaintiffs no.1 and 3 in relation to 
their respective businesses.  
2.3. Plaintiff no.1 is an international automotive and transport vehicle 
group and employs approximately 1,15,000 persons worldwide. Plaintiff 
no.1 provides a wide spectrum of transportation related products and 
services, with superior quality and high standards of safety and 
environmental care to customers.  
2.4. The plaintiffs established an Indian flagship company, Volvo India 
Pvt. Ltd. in 1996 and launched their first „VOLVO‟ bus in India in 2001, 
followed by two car models in 2007. Plaintiffs sold almost 1361 cars in 
India in the year 2020. 
2.5. The plaintiffs are the registered proprietor of the trademark „VOLVO‟ 
and „VOLVO‟ formative marks in Classes 1, 2, 16, 37 and various other 
Classes of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The earliest registration for the word 
mark „VOLVO‟ dates back to the year 1977. Details of the trademarks 
registrations of the plaintiffs‟ „VOLVO‟ marks in India have been tabulated 
at page no. 145 to 148 of the plaintiffs‟ documents filed with the plaint. The 
said marks of the plaintiffs are also registered by the plaintiffs in various 
foreign countries.  
2.6. The plaintiffs‟ „VOLVO‟ marks have acquired the status of „well-
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 3 of 11 
 
known trademarks‟ within the meaning of Section 2(1)(zg) of the Trade 
Marks Act, 1999, which fact is recognised in the judgment of Aktiebolaget 
Volvo of Sweden v. Volvo Steels Ltd. of Gujarat (India), (1998) 18 PTC 47. 
2.7. The plaintiffs are the registered domain name holders of the website, 
„www.volvobuses.com‟ and „www.volvobuses.in‟ catering to their segment 
of customers in India with the „.in‟ domain name. Additionally, the plaintiffs 
also hold the registration of the domain name „www.volvotrucks.in‟. 
2.8. Defendant no.1, Volvo White Paints Industries, is believed to be a 
partnership firm comprising the defendant no.2 and defendant no.3 
(hereinafter collectively referred to as „the defendants‟).  
2.9. In September, 2021, the plaintiffs got the knowledge that the 
defendants through the defendant no.1 were engaged in the business of 
manufacturing, dealing, selling/supplying products like wall putty, tile 
adhesive, LWC, Gypsum plaster etc., under the trade name „Volvo White 
Paints Industries‟. Pursuant thereto, the plaintiffs availed the services of an 
investigator in September - October 2021, to ascertain the business activities 
of the defendants as mentioned on their website.  
2.10. The investigation confirmed that the defendants are infringing the 
plaintiffs‟ registered and „well-known trademark‟ „VOLVO‟ as a part of 
their trade name „Volvo White Paints Industries‟ and in relation to their 
business activities. The defendants also operate the impugned domain name 
„www.volvowhite.com‟, 
which 
displays 
and 
use 
the 
mark, 
 as part of its trade name and uses the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 4 of 11 
 
plaintiffs‟   mark   in  the   meta-tags associated with the domain name, 
source code of the website hosted on the domain name. The defendants‟ 
email 
Ids 
„info@volvowhite.com‟, 
„sales@volvowhite.com‟ 
and 
„volvowhitepaints@gmail.com‟ also infringe the plaintiffs‟ mark. The 
packaging of the products of the defendant no.1 also bears the marks, 
VOLVO White Wall Putty, VOLVO White Tile adhesive, VOLVO White 
LWC, etc. which infringes the plaintiffs‟ registered and „well-known 
trademark‟ „VOLVO‟.  
2.11. The use of the mark „VOLVO‟ of the plaintiffs by the defendants in 
its trade name is intended to pass off the goods of the defendants as that of 
the plaintiffs‟. 
2.12. An application for registration of the trademark „VOLVO WHITE‟ 
(device) in Class 2 has been made by the defendants on a „proposed to be 
used basis‟, the status of which is reflected as „objected to‟ on the website of 
Indian Trademark Registry. 
2.13. Accordingly, the plaintiffs have filed the present suit. 
PROCEEDINGS IN THE SUIT 
3. 
This Court, vide order dated 31st March, 2022 granted an ex parte ad 
interim injunction in favour of the plaintiffs under I.A.4963/2022, 
restraining the defendants from using the mark „VOLVO‟. The relevant 
portion of the said order is as under: 
“25. Having heard learned counsel appearing on behalf of the 
Plaintiffs, this Court is of the view that Plaintiffs have made 
out a prima facie case for grant of ex parte ad-interim 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 5 of 11 
 
injunction. Balance of convenience lies in favour of the 
Plaintiffs and they are likely to suffer irreparable harm in case 
the injunction, as prayed for, is not granted.  
26. Accordingly, Defendants, their subsidiaries, affiliates, 
franchisees, 
proprietors, 
officers, 
servants, 
agents, 
distributors, stockists, representatives and anyone acting for 
or on their behalf are hereby restrained from using the 
Plaintiffs’ name/trademark ‘VOLVO’ and/or any other 
name/trademark confusingly or deceptively similar there to, 
in relation to their business activities of manufacturing, 
selling and/or supplying, distribution and dealing in Wall 
Putty, Tile Adhesive, LWC, Gypsum Plaster, Exterior Cement 
Paint products etc or in relation to any other goods or 
services, in any manner, including but not limited to the 
trade name ‘VOLVO White Industries’; impugned domain 
name, www.volvowhite.com; in the meta-tags associated with 
the website; the source code of website hosted on the 
impugned domain name; as a part of the email ids 
info@volvowhite.com, 
sales@volvowhite.com 
and 
volvowhitepaints@gmail.com; third party listings, references 
in social media and/or any representation made by the 
Defendants, their affiliates, subsidiaries and on their behalf, 
in terms of relief sought in paragraph 78 (i) of the present 
application.” 
4. 
Vide the aforesaid order, two Local Commissioners were also 
appointed by this Court to seize and inventorize the infringing goods bearing 
the mark „VOLVO‟. The Local Commissioners found a large stock of 
infringing goods at the premises of the defendants, which were inventorized 
by them and seized and handed over on supardari to the defendants. The 
reports of the Local Commissioners have been placed on record. 
5. 
Office report notes that the defendants no.1, 2 and 3 were served 
through e-mail and WhatsApp. An affidavit of service has been filed on 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 6 of 11 
 
behalf of the plaintiffs. As per the affidavit of service filed on behalf of the 
plaintiffs, the defendants were served through speed post, courier and e-
mail. The original speed post, courier receipts, tracking report and proof of 
service via e-mail have been filed along with the said affidavit. 
Consequently, the defendants were proceeded against ex parte on 28th July, 
2022. 
6. 
In view of the above, the counsel for the plaintiffs has filed the 
present application under Order XIII A Rules 2, 3 and 6 of the CPC for 
passing of a summary judgment.  
7. 
Counsel for the plaintiffs places reliance on the judgment of this 
Court in EBAY Inc. v. Mohd. Waseem, 2022 SCC OnLine Del 3879 to 
contend that in the event the defendants have failed to appear in the 
proceedings and voluntarily chosen not to respond to the plaint, it is 
indicative of the fact that the defendants have nothing substantial to urge, by 
way of a response to the allegations in the plaint. Counsel for the plaintiffs 
submits that this is a fit case where a Summary Judgment in terms of Order 
XIII-A of the Code of Civil Procedure, as applicable to commercial disputes 
of a specified value, read with Rule 27 of the Delhi High Court Intellectual 
Property Rights Division Rules, 2022 (in short, „IPD Rules‟), deserves to be 
passed in favour of the plaintiffs and against the defendants.  
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
8. 
I have heard the counsel for the plaintiffs and perused the record of 
the case. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 7 of 11 
 
9. 
From the averments made in the plaint and the documents filed 
therewith, the plaintiffs have been able to prove that they are the registered 
proprietors of the mark „VOLVO‟. The plaintiffs have also been able to 
show their goodwill and reputation in respect of the mark „VOLVO‟ not 
only internationally but in India as well. The mark has acquired the status of 
a „well-known trademark‟ in terms of section 2(zg) of the Trade Marks Act, 
1999. The defendants have used the word mark „VOLVO‟ in its trade name, 
which is identical to the plaintiffs‟ name, to ride on the goodwill and 
reputation of the mark of the plaintiffs. The acts of the defendants amount to 
infringement of the mark of the plaintiffs and passing off the goods of the 
defendants as that of the plaintiffs. The defendants have not only taken 
unfair advantage of the reputation and goodwill of the plaintiffs‟ mark but 
also deceive unwary consumers of their association with the plaintiffs. Such 
acts of the defendants would also lead to dilution of the plaintiffs‟ mark. 
10. 
The domain name of the defendants is also deceptively similar to that 
of the plaintiffs and is likely to deceive the public of its association with the 
plaintiffs. In Anugya Gupta v. Ajay Kumar and Anr., 2022 SCC OnLine 
Del 1922, this Court applying the principles of the trade mark law has held 
that the right of a proprietor in a domain name is entitled to equal protection. 
The user traffic may be diverted due to the use of the same or similar 
domain name, which could result in a user mistakenly accessing one domain 
name instead of the one intended. A domain name may therefore, have all 
the characteristics of a trademark and could result in an act of passing off. 
Similarly, the use of „Volvo White Paints Industries‟ as a part of their trade 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 8 of 11 
 
name/corporate name is also likely to deceive unwary consumers of their 
association with the plaintiffs. 
11. 
At this stage, it may be relevant to note that the defendants have been 
served through speed post, courier and e-mail. Moreover, the fact that local 
commissions were executed at the premises of the defendants would show 
that the defendants are aware of the pendency of the present suits. Despite 
the above, the defendants have failed to enter appearance in the suit and 
hence, were proceeded against ex parte on 28th July 2022.  
12. 
Plaintiffs have established statutory as well as common law rights on 
account of the long usage of the „VOLVO‟ marks. The plaintiffs would be 
gravely prejudiced if the defendants are permitted to use the impugned trade 
name and marks. Since the defendants have failed to enter appearance or 
even take any steps requisite to contest the present suit, despite having 
suffered an ad interim injunction order, it is evident that they have no 
defence to put forth on merits. The plaint is duly supported by the affidavit 
of the plaintiffs. I am of the opinion that no purpose would be served by 
directing the plaintiffs to lead ex parte evidence by filing an affidavit of 
examination in chief. Therefore, in my opinion, this is a fit case where a 
Summary Judgment in terms of Order XIII-A of the CPC, as applicable to 
commercial disputes of a specified value, read with Rule 27 of the IPD 
Rules, deserves to be passed in favour of the plaintiffs and against the 
defendants. Reference in this regard may be made to the judgment in Su-
Kam Power Systems Ltd. v. Kunwer Sachdev, 2019 SCC OnLine Del 
10764, has observed as under: 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 9 of 11 
 
“90. To reiterate, the intent behind incorporating the summary 
judgment procedure in the Commercial Court Act, 2015 is to 
ensure disposal of commercial disputes in a time-bound 
manner. In fact, the applicability of Order XIIIA, CPC to 
commercial disputes, demonstrates that the trial is no longer 
the default procedure/norm. 
91. Rule 3 of Order XIIIA, CPC, as applicable to commercial 
disputes, empowers the Court to grant a summary judgement 
against the defendant where the Court considers that the 
defendant has no real prospects of successfully defending the 
claim and there is no other compelling reason why the claim 
should not be disposed of before recording of oral evidence. 
The expression “real” directs the Court to examine whether 
there is a “realistic” as opposed to “fanciful” prospects of 
success. This Court is of the view that the expression “no 
genuine issue requiring a trial” in Ontario Rules of Civil 
Procedure and “no other compelling reason…..for trial” in 
Commercial Courts Act can be read mutatis mutandis. 
Consequently, Order XIIIA, CPC would be attracted if the 
Court, while hearing such an application, can make the 
necessary finding of fact, apply the law to the facts and the 
same is a proportionate, more expeditious and less expensive 
means of achieving a fair and just result. 
92. Accordingly, unlike ordinary suits, Courts need not hold 
trial in commercial suits, even if there are disputed questions 
of fact as held by the Canadian Supreme Court in Robert 
Hryniak (supra), in the event, the Court comes to the 
conclusion that the defendant lacks a real prospect of 
successfully defending the claim.” 
13. 
The aforesaid principles are fully applicable in the facts and 
circumstances of the present case and therefore, the plaintiffs are entitled to 
a summary judgment.  
14. 
In view of the above, the present application is allowed. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 10 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 10 of 11 
 
RELIEF 
15. 
The various registrations and the long usage of the mark „VOLVO‟ by 
the plaintiffs, as also the goodwill vesting in the mark „VOLVO‟, entitles the 
plaintiffs for grant of permanent injunction and decree in terms of the plaint.  
16. 
Accordingly, the present suit is decreed in terms of prayer clauses „i‟, 
„ii‟, „iii‟ and „iv‟ of the plaint. 
17. 
Since the defendants have not appeared and rendered any accounts of 
profits, the said relief as sought in prayer clauses „vii‟ cannot be granted. 
Insofar as delivery up for the purpose of destruction, as sought in prayer 
clause „v‟ is concerned, the representatives of the plaintiffs are permitted to 
visit the premises of the defendants, where the inventory is lying and take 
seizure of the infringing products for the purpose of destruction.  
18. 
Insofar as the relief of damages as sought in prayer clause „vi‟ is 
concerned, reference may be made to the judgment in Hindustan Lever Ltd. 
v. Satish Kumar, 2012 SCC OnLine Del 1378. The relevant observations 
are set out below: 
“23. One of the reasons for granting relief of punitive damages 
is that despite of service of summons/notice, the defendant had 
chosen not to appear before the court. It shows that the 
defendant is aware of the illegal activities otherwise, he ought 
to have attended the proceedings and give justification for the 
said illegal acts. Since, the defendant has maintained silence, 
therefore, the guilt of the defendant speaks for itself and the 
court, under these circumstances, feels that in order to avoid 
future infringement, relief of punitive damages is to be granted 
in favour of the plaintiff.” 
19. 
In the present case, the defendants have blatantly infringed the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 11 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 11 of 11 
 
trademark of the plaintiffs and have also failed to appear before this Court. 
Applying the above principles and considering the large quantum of 
products that have been seized by the Local Commissioners, the plaintiffs 
are entitled to damages of Rs.5,00,000. 
20. 
As regard, the prayer clause „viii‟, counsel for the plaintiffs has filed a 
statement of costs. The statement of costs shows that Rs.4,51,500/- has 
already been incurred for court fees and the fees of the Local 
Commissioners. In addition, it is claimed that expenses to the tune of Rs. 
1,33,599/- have been incurred and Rs.4,53,707/- is the legal fees. This Court 
is convinced that this is a fit case for award of actual costs to the plaintiffs.  
Accordingly, Rs.10,00,000/- is awarded to the plaintiffs as costs to be paid 
by the defendants.  
21. 
Let the decree sheet be drawn up.  
22. 
All applications are disposed of in the above terms.  
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
FEBRUARY 07, 2023 
at 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary**

Source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

**Case Details**

* Case No.: 2023/DHC/000868
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
* Date of Reserved Judgment: February 1, 2023
* Date of Decided Judgment: February 7, 2023

**Parties**

* Plaintiffs:
	+ Akciebolaget Volvo & Ors (represented by Mr. Pravin Anand and Ms. Vaishali Mittal)
	+ Incorporated in Sweden with a global deed of assignment for the trademark "VOLVO"
	+ Employ approximately 115,000 worldwide
* Defendants: Volvo White Paints Industries & Ors (no lawyer present)

**Case Overview**

The case involves a suit filed by Akciebolaget Volvo and others against Volvo White Paints Industries and others seeking:

1. Permanent injunction to restrain the defendants from infringing the plaintiffs' trademarks "VOLVO" and passing off their goods as those of the plaintiffs.
2. Ancillary reliefs

**Plaintiffs' Case**

* The plaintiffs are registered proprietors of the trademark "VOLVO" and its formative marks in various classes since 1977
* They have established an Indian flagship company, Volvo India Pvt. Ltd. in 1996 and launched their first "VOLVO" bus in India in 2001
* The plaintiffs have sold almost 1361 cars in India in the year 2020

**Outcome**

The court directed that the case be decided based on the Summary Judgment application (I.A. 1921/2023) and reserved its decision for February 7, 2023.

**PDF Source:** 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 2 from the PDF file:

**Source:** AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS VS VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf (2023/DHC/000868)

**Summary:**

* Plaintiff No.1, Aktiebolaget Volvo, assigned its global trademark "VOLVO" to Plaintiff No.2.
* The trademark was later licensed by Plaintiff No.2 to Plaintiffs No.1 and 3 for use in their respective businesses (¶¶ 2.1-2.2).
* Plaintiff No.1 is an international automotive company with over 115,000 employees worldwide, providing transportation products and services (¶ 2.3).
* The plaintiffs established a subsidiary in India, Volvo India Pvt. Ltd., and have sold over 1300 cars in India since 2007 (¶ 2.4).
* They are the registered proprietors of the trademarks "VOLVO" and "VOLVO" formative marks in various classes under the Trade Marks Act, 1999 (¶¶ 2.5-2.6).

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary:**

**PDF Source:** AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS (23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.v 2023/DHC/000868)

**Background and Facts:**

In the High Court of Delhi, a suit was filed by Aktiebolaget Volvo and others against Volvo White Paints Industries and others under CS(COMM) 198/2022. The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants were infringing their registered and well-known trademark "VOLVO" through various means, including using it as part of their trade name and domain name.

**Key Facts:**

* Plaintiffs are the registered owners of the domain names "www.volvobuses.com", "www.volvobuses.in", and "www.volvotrucks.in".
* Defendants operate a website with the domain name "www.volvowhite.com" that displays the plaintiffs' mark.
* Packaging of defendants' products bears the plaintiffs' marks, including VOLVO White Wall Putty and VOLVO White Tile adhesive.
* An application for the registration of the trademark "VOLVO WHITE" was made by defendants but is currently objected to.

**Proceedings:**

The court granted an ex parte ad interim injunction on March 31, 2022, restraining the defendants from using the mark "VOLVO". The order was based on a prima facie case and balance of convenience in favor of the plaintiffs.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

* The plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo and others, are registered owners of trademarks "VOLVO" under Section 2(1)(zg) Trade Marks Act, 1999 (recognized in the judgment of Aktiebolaget Volvo v. Volvo Steels Ltd., 1998).
* The plaintiffs hold registrations for domain names "www.volvobuses.com", "www.volvobuses.in", and "www.volvotrucks.in".
* Defendant no.1, Volvo White Paints Industries (a partnership firm), was discovered to be using the trademark "VOLVO" as part of their trade name in September 2021.
* An investigation confirmed that defendants are infringing on plaintiffs' trademarks by using them for products such as wall putty and tile adhesive.

**Dates:**

* Relevant date: September 2021
* Judgment reserved: February 1, 2023

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
**Summary of Legal Document**

**Case Details:**

* Case Number: CS(COMM) 198/2022
* Date of Hearing: 1st February, 2023 (Reserved)
* Date of Decision: 7th February, 2023
* Parties:
	+ Plaintiffs: Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors.
	+ Defendants: Vovlo White Paints Industries & Ors.

**Background:**

The plaintiffs alleged trademark infringement by the defendants for using the word mark "Volvo" in their trade name to ride on the goodwill and reputation of the plaintiffs' mark. The defendants were served through speed post, courier, and e-mail, but failed to appear in the proceedings.

**Arguments:**

* The plaintiffs relied on the judgment of EBAY Inc. v. Mohd. Waseem (2022 SCC OnLine Del 3879) to contend that the defendants' failure to respond indicates they have nothing substantial to urge against the allegations.
* Counsel for the plaintiffs argued that this is a fit case for a Summary Judgment under Order XIII-A of the Code of Civil Procedure.

**Decisions:**

* The court analyzed the record and found that:
	+ The plaintiffs have proven ownership of the "Volvo" mark and its goodwill.
	+ The defendants used the word mark "Volvo" to ride on the plaintiffs' reputation, amounting to trademark infringement and passing off.
	+ The use of the domain name by the defendants is deceptively similar to that of the plaintiffs.

**Decision:**

The court granted a Summary Judgment in favor of the plaintiffs and against the defendants.

**Source:** Section 23 of AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS. VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS. (2023/DHC/000868)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 6 from the PDF:

The plaintiffs submitted an application for a summary judgment against the defendants, who were served through speed post, courier, and e-mail. The affidavit of service filed by the plaintiffs included original receipts, tracking reports, and proof of service via e-mail. As a result, the defendants were proceeded against ex parte on July 28, 2022. Counsel for the plaintiffs argued that in light of the defendants' failure to respond, it is indicative that they have no substantial response to the allegations in the plaint. They relied on a court judgment (EBAY Inc. v. Mohd. Waseem) to support their claim. The counsel submitted that this case is suitable for a summary judgment under Order XIII-A of the CPC and Rule 27 of the Delhi High Court Intellectual Property Rights Division Rules, 2022.

**Source:** PDF: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf (Case number: CS(COMM) 198/2022 & I.A. 4963/2022(O-XXXIX R-1 & 2 of CPC))
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 6 of 11 
 
behalf of the plaintiffs. As per the affidavit of service filed on behalf of the 
plaintiffs, the defendants were served through speed post, courier and e-
mail. The original speed post, courier receipts, tracking report and proof of 
service via e-mail have been filed along with the said affidavit. 
Consequently, the defendants were proceeded against ex parte on 28th July, 
2022. 
6. 
In view of the above, the counsel for the plaintiffs has filed the 
present application under Order XIII A Rules 2, 3 and 6 of the CPC for 
passing of a summary judgment.  
7. 
Counsel for the plaintiffs places reliance on the judgment of this 
Court in EBAY Inc. v. Mohd. Waseem, 2022 SCC OnLine Del 3879 to 
contend that in the event the defendants have failed to appear in the 
proceedings and voluntarily chosen not to respond to the plaint, it is 
indicative of the fact that the defendants have nothing substantial to urge, by 
way of a response to the allegations in the plaint. Counsel for the plaintiffs 
submits that this is a fit case where a Summary Judgment in terms of Order 
XIII-A of the Code of Civil Procedure, as applicable to commercial disputes 
of a specified value, read with Rule 27 of the Delhi High Court Intellectual 
Property Rights Division Rules, 2022 (in short, „IPD Rules‟), deserves to be 
passed in favour of the plaintiffs and against the defendants.  
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
8. 
I have heard the counsel for the plaintiffs and perused the record of 
the case. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 7 from the provided PDF:

**Case Details:** CS(COMM) 198/2022 & I.A. 4963/2022(O-XXXIX R-1 & 2 of CPC)

The court has concluded that the plaintiffs (Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors.) have proven their ownership of the "VOLVO" mark and have demonstrated goodwill and reputation internationally, including in India. The defendants' use of the word mark "VOLVO" amounts to trademark infringement and passing off.

**Key Findings:**

1. Plaintiffs are registered proprietors of the "VOLVO" mark.
2. Defendants have used a deceptively similar domain name, likely leading to public deception.
3. Court has held that the right of a proprietor in a domain name is entitled to equal protection (Anugya Gupta v. Ajay Kumar & Anr.).

**Proceedings:** The court has reserved judgment on February 1, 2023, and decided on February 7, 2023.

**PDF Source:** 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf (2023/DHC/000868)
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 7 of 11 
 
9. 
From the averments made in the plaint and the documents filed 
therewith, the plaintiffs have been able to prove that they are the registered 
proprietors of the mark „VOLVO‟. The plaintiffs have also been able to 
show their goodwill and reputation in respect of the mark „VOLVO‟ not 
only internationally but in India as well. The mark has acquired the status of 
a „well-known trademark‟ in terms of section 2(zg) of the Trade Marks Act, 
1999. The defendants have used the word mark „VOLVO‟ in its trade name, 
which is identical to the plaintiffs‟ name, to ride on the goodwill and 
reputation of the mark of the plaintiffs. The acts of the defendants amount to 
infringement of the mark of the plaintiffs and passing off the goods of the 
defendants as that of the plaintiffs. The defendants have not only taken 
unfair advantage of the reputation and goodwill of the plaintiffs‟ mark but 
also deceive unwary consumers of their association with the plaintiffs. Such 
acts of the defendants would also lead to dilution of the plaintiffs‟ mark. 
10. 
The domain name of the defendants is also deceptively similar to that 
of the plaintiffs and is likely to deceive the public of its association with the 
plaintiffs. In Anugya Gupta v. Ajay Kumar and Anr., 2022 SCC OnLine 
Del 1922, this Court applying the principles of the trade mark law has held 
that the right of a proprietor in a domain name is entitled to equal protection. 
The user traffic may be diverted due to the use of the same or similar 
domain name, which could result in a user mistakenly accessing one domain 
name instead of the one intended. A domain name may therefore, have all 
the characteristics of a trademark and could result in an act of passing off. 
Similarly, the use of „Volvo White Paints Industries‟ as a part of their trade 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary:
Page 8 of the PDF "23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS" from case CS(COMM) 198/2022 (Source: PDF provided, no URL or hyperlink given).

The page discusses a suit filed by Aktiebolaget Volvo and others against Volvo White Paints Industries and others.

**Key points:**

* The court notes that the defendants' use of the mark "VOLVO" is likely to deceive consumers into believing it's associated with the plaintiffs.
* Despite being served through various means, the defendants failed to enter an appearance or take any steps in the suit.
* The plaintiffs have established statutory and common law rights to the "VOLVO" mark due to its long usage.
* A Summary Judgment is considered in favor of the plaintiffs under Order XIII-A of CPC, with reference to Su-Kam Power Systems Ltd. v. Kunwer Sachdev (2019 SCC OnLine Del 10764).

**Dates and names:**

* Reserved on February 1, 2023
* Decided on February 7, 2023
* Mr. Pravin Anand with Ms. Vaishali Mittal (Advocates)
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 8 of 11 
 
name/corporate name is also likely to deceive unwary consumers of their 
association with the plaintiffs. 
11. 
At this stage, it may be relevant to note that the defendants have been 
served through speed post, courier and e-mail. Moreover, the fact that local 
commissions were executed at the premises of the defendants would show 
that the defendants are aware of the pendency of the present suits. Despite 
the above, the defendants have failed to enter appearance in the suit and 
hence, were proceeded against ex parte on 28th July 2022.  
12. 
Plaintiffs have established statutory as well as common law rights on 
account of the long usage of the „VOLVO‟ marks. The plaintiffs would be 
gravely prejudiced if the defendants are permitted to use the impugned trade 
name and marks. Since the defendants have failed to enter appearance or 
even take any steps requisite to contest the present suit, despite having 
suffered an ad interim injunction order, it is evident that they have no 
defence to put forth on merits. The plaint is duly supported by the affidavit 
of the plaintiffs. I am of the opinion that no purpose would be served by 
directing the plaintiffs to lead ex parte evidence by filing an affidavit of 
examination in chief. Therefore, in my opinion, this is a fit case where a 
Summary Judgment in terms of Order XIII-A of the CPC, as applicable to 
commercial disputes of a specified value, read with Rule 27 of the IPD 
Rules, deserves to be passed in favour of the plaintiffs and against the 
defendants. Reference in this regard may be made to the judgment in Su-
Kam Power Systems Ltd. v. Kunwer Sachdev, 2019 SCC OnLine Del 
10764, has observed as under: 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

nodes.title: Page 9
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 9 from the provided PDF (23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS):

The High Court of Delhi, in CS(COMM) 198/2022, held that:

* The intent behind incorporating summary judgment procedure in the Commercial Courts Act is to ensure disposal of commercial disputes in a time-bound manner (para 90).
* Rule 3 of Order XIIIA, CPC empowers the court to grant a summary judgment where the defendant has no real prospects of successfully defending the claim and there are no compelling reasons for trial.
* The expression "real" directs the court to examine whether there are realistic prospects of success, not fanciful ones.
* In commercial suits, courts can apply summary judgment without holding a full trial, even with disputed facts, if they conclude that the defendant lacks real prospects of successfully defending the claim (para 92).

The Court concluded: "The aforesaid principles are fully applicable in the facts and circumstances of the present case... therefore, the plaintiffs are entitled to a summary judgment" (para 13). The application was allowed.

Source: AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf, Case No: CS(COMM) 198/2022, Judgment Date: 07.02.2023
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 9 of 11 
 
“90. To reiterate, the intent behind incorporating the summary 
judgment procedure in the Commercial Court Act, 2015 is to 
ensure disposal of commercial disputes in a time-bound 
manner. In fact, the applicability of Order XIIIA, CPC to 
commercial disputes, demonstrates that the trial is no longer 
the default procedure/norm. 
91. Rule 3 of Order XIIIA, CPC, as applicable to commercial 
disputes, empowers the Court to grant a summary judgement 
against the defendant where the Court considers that the 
defendant has no real prospects of successfully defending the 
claim and there is no other compelling reason why the claim 
should not be disposed of before recording of oral evidence. 
The expression “real” directs the Court to examine whether 
there is a “realistic” as opposed to “fanciful” prospects of 
success. This Court is of the view that the expression “no 
genuine issue requiring a trial” in Ontario Rules of Civil 
Procedure and “no other compelling reason…..for trial” in 
Commercial Courts Act can be read mutatis mutandis. 
Consequently, Order XIIIA, CPC would be attracted if the 
Court, while hearing such an application, can make the 
necessary finding of fact, apply the law to the facts and the 
same is a proportionate, more expeditious and less expensive 
means of achieving a fair and just result. 
92. Accordingly, unlike ordinary suits, Courts need not hold 
trial in commercial suits, even if there are disputed questions 
of fact as held by the Canadian Supreme Court in Robert 
Hryniak (supra), in the event, the Court comes to the 
conclusion that the defendant lacks a real prospect of 
successfully defending the claim.” 
13. 
The aforesaid principles are fully applicable in the facts and 
circumstances of the present case and therefore, the plaintiffs are entitled to 
a summary judgment.  
14. 
In view of the above, the present application is allowed. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
**Court Decision**

Case Number: CS(COMM) 198/2022 & I.A. 4963/2022(O-XXXIX R-1&2ofCPC)
Date of Decree: February 7, 2023
Judge: Amit Bansal

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi passed a decree in favor of the plaintiffs, AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS., against VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS. The case involved trademark infringement by the defendants.

**Facts and Arguments**

* The plaintiffs claimed registration of their trademarks "VOLVO" since 1956.
* The defendants allegedly infringed the plaintiff's trademark rights, resulting in large quantities of seized products.
* The defendants failed to appear before the court or provide justification for their actions.

**Decisions**

1. Permanent injunction granted against the defendants.
2. Damages of Rs.5,00,000 awarded to the plaintiffs as punitive damages.
3. Actual costs of Rs.10,00,000 awarded to the plaintiffs to be paid by the defendants.
4. The representatives of the plaintiffs were permitted to visit the premises of the defendants to seize and destroy the infringing products.

**Important Parties, Dates, and Amounts**

* Parties: AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS., VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.
* Case Number: CS(COMM) 198/2022
* Date of Decree: February 7, 2023
* Damages Awarded: Rs.5,00,000
* Actual Costs Awarded: Rs.10,00,000

Source:
23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf
tree_structure.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

nodes.title: Page 10
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 10 from the PDF:

**Case Details**

* Case no.: 2023/DHC/000868
* Court: High Court of Delhi
* Date: February 7, 2023
* Parties:
	+ Plaintiffs: Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors.
	+ Defendants: Vovlo White Paints Industries & Ors.

**Judgment**

* The court grants permanent injunction and decree in favor of the plaintiffs against the defendants for infringement of the mark "VOLVO".
* The suit is decreed in terms of prayer clauses i, ii, iii, and iv.
* The defendant's accounts of profits are not rendered, so relief sought in prayer clause vii cannot be granted.
* Seizure of infringing products at the defendant's premises for destruction is permitted.

**Citation**

* Judgement cited: Hindustan Lever Ltd. v. Satish Kumar, 2012 SCC OnLine Del 1378

Source: PDF file "23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf"
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 10 of 11 
 
RELIEF 
15. 
The various registrations and the long usage of the mark „VOLVO‟ by 
the plaintiffs, as also the goodwill vesting in the mark „VOLVO‟, entitles the 
plaintiffs for grant of permanent injunction and decree in terms of the plaint.  
16. 
Accordingly, the present suit is decreed in terms of prayer clauses „i‟, 
„ii‟, „iii‟ and „iv‟ of the plaint. 
17. 
Since the defendants have not appeared and rendered any accounts of 
profits, the said relief as sought in prayer clauses „vii‟ cannot be granted. 
Insofar as delivery up for the purpose of destruction, as sought in prayer 
clause „v‟ is concerned, the representatives of the plaintiffs are permitted to 
visit the premises of the defendants, where the inventory is lying and take 
seizure of the infringing products for the purpose of destruction.  
18. 
Insofar as the relief of damages as sought in prayer clause „vi‟ is 
concerned, reference may be made to the judgment in Hindustan Lever Ltd. 
v. Satish Kumar, 2012 SCC OnLine Del 1378. The relevant observations 
are set out below: 
“23. One of the reasons for granting relief of punitive damages 
is that despite of service of summons/notice, the defendant had 
chosen not to appear before the court. It shows that the 
defendant is aware of the illegal activities otherwise, he ought 
to have attended the proceedings and give justification for the 
said illegal acts. Since, the defendant has maintained silence, 
therefore, the guilt of the defendant speaks for itself and the 
court, under these circumstances, feels that in order to avoid 
future infringement, relief of punitive damages is to be granted 
in favour of the plaintiff.” 
19. 
In the present case, the defendants have blatantly infringed the

nodes.title: Page 11
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 11 from the PDF:

**Case Details**

* Case Number: 2023/DHC/000868
* CS(COMM) 198/2022 & I.A. 4963/2022(O-XXXIX R-1 & 2 of CPC)
* Parties: Aktebolaget Volvo & Ors. (Plaintiffs) vs Vovlo White Paints Industries & Ors. (Defendants)

**Decree**

* Damages of Rs. 5,00,000 awarded to plaintiffs for trademark infringement.
* Actual costs of Rs. 10,00,000 awarded to plaintiffs as part of legal fees and expenses (Rs. 4,51,500 court fees, Rs. 1,33,599 expenses, and Rs. 4,53,707 legal fees).
* Decree sheet to be drawn up.

**Judgment Date**: February 7, 2023

**Counsel for Plaintiffs**: Mr. Pravin Anand with Ms. Vaishali Mittal and Mr. Karan Kamra.

PDF Source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 11 of 11 
 
trademark of the plaintiffs and have also failed to appear before this Court. 
Applying the above principles and considering the large quantum of 
products that have been seized by the Local Commissioners, the plaintiffs 
are entitled to damages of Rs.5,00,000. 
20. 
As regard, the prayer clause „viii‟, counsel for the plaintiffs has filed a 
statement of costs. The statement of costs shows that Rs.4,51,500/- has 
already been incurred for court fees and the fees of the Local 
Commissioners. In addition, it is claimed that expenses to the tune of Rs. 
1,33,599/- have been incurred and Rs.4,53,707/- is the legal fees. This Court 
is convinced that this is a fit case for award of actual costs to the plaintiffs.  
Accordingly, Rs.10,00,000/- is awarded to the plaintiffs as costs to be paid 
by the defendants.  
21. 
Let the decree sheet be drawn up.  
22. 
All applications are disposed of in the above terms.  
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
FEBRUARY 07, 2023
